content.title: Pulse Examination
content.summary: Systematic pulse examination is a cornerstone of vascular assessment. Proper technique at standard anatomical locations, combined with pulse grading and documentation, provides essential information about arterial patency and guides further workup.
content.definition: The systematic palpation of arterial pulsations at standard anatomical locations to assess arterial patency, character, and potential pathology

pulse_grading.documentation: Record grade for each pulse examined with date

radial.location: Lateral wrist, between radial styloid and flexor carpi radialis
radial.clinical_notes: Most commonly assessed, good for rate/rhythm

ulnar.location: Medial wrist, lateral to flexor carpi ulnaris tendon
ulnar.clinical_notes: Part of Allen test, may be difficult to palpate

brachial.location: Antecubital fossa, medial to biceps tendon

axillary.technique: Arm abducted, palpate high in axilla
axillary.clinical_notes: Difficult, may use for trauma assessment

subclavian.clinical_notes: Often not palpable; bruit more useful

femoral.location: Midpoint between ASIS and pubic symphysis (inguinal ligament)
femoral.technique: Firm pressure, may need two hands in obese patients
femoral.clinical_notes: Key inflow assessment, also assess for bruit

technique.standard: Patient supine, knee flexed 30°, fingers from posterior

popliteal.clinical_notes: Most difficult pulse, assess for aneurysm (expansile vs transmitted)

dorsalis_pedis.location: Dorsum of foot, lateral to extensor hallucis longus tendon
dorsalis_pedis.technique: Light pressure, may need to search
dorsalis_pedis.clinical_notes: Absent in 10% of normal population (congenital variant)

posterior_tibial.clinical_notes: More reliable than DP, less anatomic variation

carotid.location: Anterior to sternocleidomastoid, at level of thyroid cartilage

technique.approach: Gentle pressure, one side at a time
technique.caution: Never occlude both simultaneously, avoid pressure at bifurcation

temporal.clinical_notes: Tender, non-pulsatile = consider giant cell arteritis

abdominal_aorta.technique: Deep palpation with two hands straddling aorta

aneurysm_detection.femoral: Look for other aneurysms if present

definition.@value: Systematic palpation of arterial pulsations at standard locations to assess vascular status

learning_objectives: Locate and palpate standard arterial pulse points
Describe proper technique for difficult pulses (popliteal)
Correlate pulse findings with level of arterial disease
clinical_pearls: Popliteal pulse: flex knee and approach from posterior
Dorsalis pedis absent in 10% of normal patients - check PT
Popliteal aneurysm: 50% bilateral, 30-50% have AAA too
If unsure about pulse, use handheld Doppler to confirm
